Objects in Javascript

Arun v Â  in India
Sat Jun 12 2021
  • JavaScript
  • Object

# What is JavaScript Object

JavaScript is designed based on object. An object is a collection of properties, and a property is an association between a name (or key) and a value. A property's value can be a function, in which case the property is known as a method. In addition to objects that are predefined in the browser, you can define your own objects. Let's learn how to use objects, properties, functions, and methods, and how to create your own objects.

# Prototype

A JavaScript object has properties associated with it. A property of an object can be explained as a variable that is attached to the object. Object properties are basically the same as ordinary JavaScript variables, except for the attachment to objects. The properties of an object define the characteristics of the object. You access the properties of an object with a simple dot-notation:

# Create object

Creating a simple object

let user = {
    name: 'kain',
    age: 79,
    favColors: ["red", "blue", "green"]
}
console.log(user.name)
// output
// kain

# Set value in object

adding new value to object

let user = {
    name: "kain",
}
user["age"] = 30
console.log(user);
console.log(user.age)
// output
// {name: "kain", age: 30}
// 30

you can also have space while naming key but we could not access it with dot operator but we could access like as follows

let user = {
    name: "kain"
}
user["your age"] = 34;
console.log(user["your age"]);
// output
// 34

# Enumerate the properties of an object

Starting with ECMAScript (opens new window) 5, there are three native ways to list/traverse object properties:

  • for...in loops This method traverses all enumerable properties of an object and its prototype chain.
  • Object.keys(o) This method returns an array with all the own (not in the prototype chain) enumerable properties' names ("keys") of an object o.
  • Object.getOwnPropertyNames(o) This method returns an array containing all own properties' names (enumerable or not) of an object o.

# Cycling through key in Object

we are using for...in loop to cycle through object to get it's keys, the we are going to use those keys to get the value for those associative keys

let user = {
    name: "kain",
    age: 83
}
for (let key in obj) {
    console.log('Key: ' + key + ', Value: ' + user[key])
}
// output
// Key: name, Value: kain
// Key: name, Value: 83

# Using Object.Keys() and Object.getOwnPropertyNames()

Object.Keys() and Object.getOwnPropertyNames() methods will take in target object as parameter and return array of that objects key which in turn we can used to loop through and get the value

let user = {
    name: "kain",
    age: 83
}
let keys = Object.Keys(user) // ['name', 'age']
console.log("using Object.Keys()")
for (let i = 0; i < keys.length; i++) {
    let key = keys[i];
    let value = user[key];
    console.log(value);
}
console.log("using Object.getOwnPropertyNames()")
let newKeys = Object.getOwnPropertyNames(user) // ['name', 'age']
for (let i = 0; i < newKeys.length; i++) {
    let key = newKeys[i];
    let value = user[key];
    console.log(value);
}
// output
// using Object.Keys()
// kain
// 83
// using Object.getOwnPropertyNames()
// kain
// 83

# Using a constructor function

Alternatively, you can create an object with these two steps:

  • Define the object type by writing a constructor function. There is a strong convention, with good reason, to use a capital initial letter.
  • Create an instance of the object with new.

To define an object type, create a function for the object type that specifies its name, properties, and methods. For example, suppose you want to create an object type for cars. You want this type of object to be called Car, and you want it to have properties for make, model, and year. To do this, you would write the following function

function User(name, age, email) {
  this.name = name;
  this.age = age;
  this.email = email;
}
let user1 = new User("kain", 65, "kain@mail.com")
let user2 = new User("taker", 85, "taker@mail.com")
console.log(user1)
console.log(user2)
// output
// { name: "kain", age: 65, email: "kain@mail.com" }
// { name: "taker", age: 85, email: "taker@mail.com" }

# Using Object.create() method

Objects can also be created using the Object.create() method. This method can be very useful, because it allows you to choose the prototype object for the object you want to create, without having to define a constructor function.

// robot properties and method encapsulation
var robot = {
  color: 'green', // Default value of properties
  displayType: function() {  // Method which will display type of robot
    console.log("Color: ", this.type);
  }
};

// Create new robot type called robot1
var robot1 = Object.create(Animal);
robot1.displayType(); // Color: green

// Create new robot type called robot2
var robot2 = Object.create(Animal);
fish.type = 'red';
fish.displayType(); // Color: red
// output
// Color: green
// Color: red

# Defining methods

A method is a function associated with an object, or, put differently, a method is a property of an object that is a function. Methods are defined the way normal functions are defined, except that they have to be assigned as the property of an object. See also method definitions for more details. An example is:

// objectName.methodname = functionName;
var user = {
    sayPing: function(params) {
        // ...do something
    }

    // OR THIS WORKS TOO

    myOtherMethod(params) {
        // ...do something else
    }
};

where objectName is an existing object, methodname is the name you are assigning to the method, and functionName is the name of the function.

You can then call the method in the context of the object as follows:

object.methodname(params);

you can also access the value outside the method within the parent object context this key word

let user = {
    name: 'john',
    getName() {
        console.log("my name is " + this.name);
    }
}
user.getName();
// output
// my name is john

we can also use a external function as method in object using the following way

function getName(){
    console.log("my name is " + this.name);
}
function User(name, getName) {
    this.name = name;
    this.getName = getName;
}
let user = new User("john", getName);
user.getName();
// output
// my name is john

# Deleting properties

We can remove a non-inherited property by using the delete operator. The following code shows how to remove a property.

let robot = {
    color: "red",
    tag: "delta"
}
console.log("Before deleting", robot);
delete robot.tag;
console.log("After deleting", robot);
// output
// Before deleting { color: "red", tag: "delta" }
// After Deleting { color: "red" }
